screens.headline: Why do traders pay $500 for a piece of paper?
screens.text: Options are the financial world's most misunderstood tool. In the next 5 minutes, you'll understand what Wall Street took years to learn.

screens.headline: An Option is a Contract
screens.text: An option gives you the RIGHT (not obligation) to buy or sell a stock at a specific price before a specific date.

screens.headline: Think of it like concert tickets
screens.text: You buy a $50 ticket for a concert next month. You have the RIGHT to go, but you don't HAVE to. If you get sick, you're only out $50. But if tickets resell for $500, you can go OR sell your ticket for a profit.

reveal_sections.label: Your choice to attend = Your right to exercise

cards.definition: The price you pay to buy the option
The price you can buy/sell the stock at
The deadline - after this, option is worthless
The stock the option is based on

screens.question: What does an option give you?
options: The obligation to buy a stock
The right (but not obligation) to buy or sell a stock
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! It's a RIGHT, not an obligation. That's what makes options less risky than stocks in some ways.
screens.explanation_wrong: Not quite. An option gives you a choice - the RIGHT but not OBLIGATION to act.

screens.question: You buy an option for $5 per share. What's the MOST you can lose?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! When you BUY an option, your maximum loss is always just the premium you paid. That's the beauty of options.
screens.explanation_wrong: Think about it: if you paid $5 for a concert ticket and don't go, what did you lose? Just the $5 ticket price.

screens.question: AAPL is at $150. You pay $4 for an option to buy it at $155 anytime this month. Next week, AAPL jumps to $165. What should you do?
options: Exercise your option - buy at $155 and sell at $165
Let it expire - you can't make money
screens.explanation_correct: Boom! You can buy at $155 (your strike) and immediately sell at $165 (market price) = $10 profit. Minus your $4 premium = $6 net profit per share. That's a 150% return!
screens.explanation_wrong: Look at the numbers: You can buy at $155 (your locked-in strike), but the stock is worth $165. That's $10 profit per share!

cards.back: A CONTRACT giving you the RIGHT (not obligation) to buy or sell a stock at a set price before a set date
Only the PREMIUM you paid - nothing more
LEVERAGE: Control $15,000 of stock for just $300. Limited downside, unlimited upside.

screens.badge_description: You understand what options actually are
